column3:
Qhoterl Pasol wants to bring a touch of style to some otherwise drab textiles.

※Please note that the difficulty of this quest has been synced to your current level. Furthermore, you may not proceed with a class or job that is different from when you accepted this quest.
Deliver the requested items to Qhoterl Pasol.

<If(Equal(IntegerParameter(4),16))><If(LessThan(IntegerParameter(1),IntegerParameter(2)))>Mine splendid purple pigment in the Blind Forest of Yx'Maja<Else/>Deliver the splendid purple pigment to Qhoterl Pasol</If><Else/><If(Equal(IntegerParameter(4),17))><If(LessThan(IntegerParameter(1),IntegerParameter(2)))>Gather splendid turmeric in the Blind Forest of Yx'Maja<Else/>Deliver the splendid turmeric to Qhoterl Pasol</If><Else/><If(Equal(IntegerParameter(4),18))><If(LessThan(IntegerParameter(1),IntegerParameter(2)))>Catch a splendid spiralshell in south Mjrl's Regret<Else/>Deliver the splendid spiralshell to Qhoterl Pasol</If><Else/></If></If></If>.
We Qitari are experts at weaving clothes, bags, and so on, which we decorate in the traditional manner using various colors.
But with so many of us preoccupied with excavating the caves, we've had little time to gather the raw ingredients for producing the dyes we need.
Were an altruistic volunteer to bring me a small quantity of purple pigment, I think a reward of some sort would be in order.
Were an altruistic volunteer to bring me a small quantity of turmeric, I think a reward of some sort would be in order.
Were an altruistic volunteer to bring me a spiralshell, I think a reward of some sort would be in order. And were said volunteer to use fruit worms as bait, I'm sure they'd snag one in a jiffy!
The Blind Forest of Yx'Maja would be an excellent place to begin your search, but watch out for beasties, especially those tarichuks. Oh, I can't stand them!
The Blind Forest of Yx'Maja would be an excellent place to begin your search, but watch out for beasties, especially those tarichuks. Oh, I can't stand them!
The southern part of Mjrl's Regret is where you're most likely to find one, but don't let those caracals catch you by surprise!
Do you have something for me, by any chance? I'm <Emphasis>dye</Emphasis>-ing to see it! <snort>
With this, we'll be able to bring a touch of Ronkan elegance to our textiles. The patterns with which we adorn ourselves come from their ancient culture, you see.
Those that feature a pair of straight, parallel lines represent harmony, whereas spirals are a symbol of the never-ending cycle of nature, for example.
Perhaps you would consider wearing some of our traditional garments yourself? I think you'd look rather fetching in one of our hats!
